Expectation1: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation1: A new furniture order comes in, and the carpenter should estimate material requirements and order supplies as needed
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I stood in my workshop, the scent of fresh pine filling the air as I reviewed the new furniture order. The client wanted a custom dining set, and I needed to estimate the materials and place the order by tonight if I wanted to meet the deadline. My mind raced through measurements and supply lists, but the church bell rang in the distance, reminding me of the evening service. As a Christian, I was expected to be there, not just to worship but to help set up for the community dinner afterward. My pastor had spoken to me last week about the importance of consistency and fellowship. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my hands itching to get back to the blueprints, my heart tugged toward the church doors. I knew I couldn’t be in two places at once, and the thought of letting someone down—either my client or my church family—made my chest tighten. I stared at the unfinished plans on my workbench, torn between the demands of my craft and the call of my faith, unsure which path to take.
